awd_titl_txt: Anisotropic Energy Functionals in Geometric Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Anisotropic energies were introduced by Gibbs in the 19th century to model the equilibrium shape of crystals and, more generally, the surface tension at the interfaces of any two different materials. An increasing interest has been devoted to the corresponding geometric variational problems in mathematics. Minimizing the area functional, the simplest anisotropic energy, is one of the most famous examples in this class of problems. It dates back to the work of Lagrange in 1760 and has had a major impact both in physics and in mathematics. Jesse Douglas was awarded the first Fields Medal in 1936 for his results on this topic; yet, a variety of basic questions remain open, especially in the more general anisotropic setting. The goal of this project is to develop new theories and techniques to improve the state of the art of anisotropic geometric variational problems.
 
This project aims to increase our understanding of critical points for general elliptic integrands. In contrast to the reach theory of minimal surfaces, i.e., critical points of the area functional, very little is understood in the anisotropic framework. One of the main themes of this project is the existence of anisotropic minimal hypersurfaces in closed Riemannian manifolds. This is a fascinating and central question in geometric analysis, which has been answered for the area functional by Pitts, Schoen, Simon and Yau in the eighties. The investigator will address the more general anisotropic setting, broadening the reach of the min-max theory. This will require a refined analysis of the structure of varifolds, which will find applications also in the construction of geometric flows. Another goal of this project is to study existence and regularity results for energy minimizers of the set-theoretic Plateau problem in general metric spaces. This investigation will be then further refined for size minimizer rectifiable currents. Moreover, the investigator will study the behavior of hypersurfaces with almost constant anisotropic mean curvature. Finally, the stability and regularity conjectures in optimal branched transport will be addressed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During this project the PI has achieved significant progress in the anisotropic minimal surface theory. Anisotropic energies are used to model the surface tension at the interfaces of different materials. For instance, they allow to describe the equilibrium shapes of crystals. In contrast to the rich theory of the area functional, very little is known in the anisotropic framework. The PI has investigated three main problems: the analysis of the regularity and singularity of equilibrium shapes for anisotropic energies, the characterization of these equilibria, and the stability of such critical points.

More precisely, the PI and his coauthor Kolasinski have obtained equivalence results among the ellipticity conditions for anisotropic energies, that are suited to study the regularity of anisotropic minimal surfaces. In joint work with Lussardi, the PI has extended to the anisotropic setting the existence of solutions for the Kirchhoff-Plateau problem. Together with Kolasinski and Santilli, the PI has characterized the critical points of the anisotropic isoperimetric problem, and with Gioffre the PI has obtained stability estimates for these equilibrium shapes. The PI has studied with La Manna the critical points of the nonlocal gaussian isoperimetric problem and has obtained with Khajavirad scalable LP relaxations with theoretical performance guarantees for the K-means clustering problem. Finally, the PI has solved the stability conjecture in optimal branched transport in collaboration with Colombo and Marchese, also providing the Lagrangian counterpart with Colombo, Marchese, Pegon and Prouff.

While conducting this project, the PI has advised undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs. The PI has disseminated the outcome of this project by delivering 40 talks at international conferences, seminar series and workshops. Moreover the PI has organized several seminar series and conferences. Finally the PI has given special topic classes related to the topics of this project.


Last Modified: 01/11/2023
Modified by: Antonio De Rosa
